title.narrative: Emergency Nutrition Interventions in Yaya Gulele and Hidhabu Abote Woredas of Oromia Region

description.narrative:
The overall objective of this project is to provide lifesaving emergency nutrition services, thereby contributing to reduction of morbidities and mortalities associated with malnutrition amongst under-five children and pregnant and lactating women in two drought affected Woredas, Yaya Gulele and Hidhabu Abote, in Oromia region. This nine months emergency nutrition response will focus both on providing tailored and effective technical and logistics support to the Woreda Health Offices to address their need and effectively treat and manage severe and moderate acute malnutrition (SAM and MAM) in children under five years and pregnant and lactating women and minimize sufferings associated with malnutrition in what is predicted to be a lengthy and worrying hunger season. WVE will support the Woreda Health Offices (WrHOs) to deliver high quality full CMAM services including treating severely malnourished children with medical complication in SCs, treating and feeding malnourished children without complication at OTP, rehabilitating at risk and moderately malnourished children to prevent deterioration in to SAM through Targeted Supplementary Feeding Program (TSFP), and community mobilization in these 2 hot spot priority two (P2) Woredas.
The project will be implemented in both Yaya Gulele and Hidhabu Abote Woredas as the under-nutrition alongside the hunger season is expected to extend until the 2016 belg harvests. In order to attain the project objective, it employs core strategies including capacity building, community mobilization and participation strengthening the existing health programs and integration of CMAM in to various Areas Programs (APs) currently run by WVE. The project will directly benefit 3,109 children with SAM amp MAM and 1,663 malnourished pregnant and lactating (PLW) mothers in these Woredas. This project prioritizes those most vulnerable groups of people – children with high degree of vulnerability like children with disability as primary beneficiaries, particularly malnourished under-five children and pregnant and lactating women in all steps of the project implementation. In addition, the project is designed to integrate gender throughout the implementation. The project aims at achieving outputs including strengthened CMAM program, increased knowledge and skills on SAM and TSFP management, early detection and management of SAM children at SC/OTP and rehabilitate at risk and moderately malnourished children to prevent deterioration. The project will be staffed with health professionals who have proven experience on emergency nutrition programs on similar settings.
